clusters.title: British prime minister sacks ambassador to US over links to Epstein
clusters.neutral_headline: UK Prime Minister Sacks Ambassador to US Over Epstein Ties
bullet_summary: I t came after a newspaper published emails it said showed Mandelson telling Epstein to "fight for early release" shortly before Epstein was sentenced to 18 months in prison

items.title: British prime minister sacks ambassador to US over links to Epstein
items.standfirst: Prime Minister Keir Starmer sacks the British ambassador to the US, Peter Mandelson, over ties to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
items.content: Prime Minister Keir Starmer sacks the British ambassador to the US, Peter Mandelson, over ties to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

items.title: UK PM fires Britain's ambassador to US over links to Jeffrey Epstein
items.standfirst: I t came after a newspaper published emails it said showed Mandelson telling Epstein to "fight for early release" shortly before Epstein was sentenced to 18 months in prison.
items.content: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has fired the UK's ambassador to the US, Peter Mandelson, over his links to the convicted pedophile Jeffrey Epstein.In a statement in the House of Commons on Thursday, Foreign Office minister Stephen Doughty said the decision came after the publication this week of emails Mandelson sent to Epstein."In light of the additional information in emails written by Peter Mandelson, the prime minister has asked the foreign secretary to withdraw him as ambassador," the Foreign Office said in a statement.READ MORE: Violence has become a regular part of American political life"The emails show that the depth and extent of Peter Mandelson's relationship with Jeffrey Epstein is materially different from that known at the time of his appointment," it added.On Wednesday, The Sun newspaper published emails that it said showed Mandelson telling Epstein to "fight for early release" shortly before Epstein was sentenced to 18 months in prison."I think the world of you," Mandelson told him before he began his sentence for soliciting prostitution from a minor in June 2008.The emails were published after the Democrats on the House Oversight Committee released a 50th birthday album compiled in 2003 for Epstein, who at the time was a wealthy and well-connected financier. In that album, Mandelson called Epstein "my best pal" in a handwritten note.More to come.

ai_summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer fired the British ambassador to the US.
The ambassador, Peter Mandelson, had links to Jeffrey Epstein.
Emails reportedly showed Mandelson advising Epstein on early release.
The emails were published by a newspaper before Epstein's sentencing.
Mandelson's ties to Epstein led to his dismissal.

clusters.title: Thousands in government funding going unclaimed by millions
clusters.neutral_headline: Millions Unclaimed for Government Dental Funding in Australia

items.title: Thousands in government funding going unclaimed by millions
items.standfirst: The Australian Dental Association says the reason for the low usage rates among Australians is that accessing the scheme is confusing.
items.content: The Australian Dental Association says the reason for the low usage rates among Australians is that accessing the scheme is confusing.

items.title: Thousands in government funding going unclaimed by millions of Aussies
items.standfirst: Despite 2.4 million kids being eligible, only 600,000 Australians have accessed a government program that provides $1132 over two years for dental services for children.
items.content: Despite 2.4 million kids being eligible, only 600,000 Australians have accessed a government program that provides $1132 over two years for dental services for children.Uptake for the Child Dental Benefits Schedule has been stuck at 40 per cent since it was introduced a decade ago.The Australian Dental Association says the reason for the low adoption is that accessing the scheme is confusing. LIVE UPDATES: Pro-Trump activist Charlie Kirk assassinated on US college campusWhile the government promotes it on social media, it has admitted it could be better advertised to increase numbers."It's a terrific opportunity for relatively low-income families to get access to high-quality dental care for their kids and build that strong oral health for a lifetime," Health Minister Mark Butler said.To qualify for the benefits, a child must be aged under 18 and their family must receive a government payment like family tax benefit A, or a parenting payment. Australians can check their eligibility for the use-it-or-lose-it benefit on MyGov and can call their dentist ahead of time to confirm that they participate in the scheme.The program covers dental services such as examinations, x-rays, cleaning, fissure sealing, fillings, root canals, and extractions, although it doesn't cover whitening or braces.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: Millions of Australians are not using government dental funding.
The Australian Dental Association cited confusion as a reason.
The program provides $1132 over two years for children's dental.
Only 600,000 Australians have accessed the program.
2.4 million children are eligible for the dental funding.

clusters.title: Ex-radio host's 'sexist' Matildas comments breached decency rules
clusters.neutral_headline: Radio Host's "Sexist" Matildas Comments Breached Decency Rules

items.title: Ex-radio host's 'sexist' Matildas comments breached decency rules
items.standfirst: A months-long investigation has ruled that the 54-year-old comedian's remarks were sexist and derogatory.
items.content: Triple M breached decency rules when the radio station broadcast former presenter Marty Sheargold's "derogatory" and "sexist" comments about the Matildas, the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) has found.Sheargold left the station and his show was cancelled in February after the 54-year-old said he would "rather hammer a nail through the head of my penis" than watch the Matildas play in the Asian Cup next year.He also said the team reminded him of "year 10 girls".READ MORE: Sussan Ley says Jacinta Price saga isn't threatening her leadership"All the infighting and all the friendship issues, 'the coach hates me and I hate bloody training and Michelle's being a b----'," he said at the time."Now I'm sorry to undermine the whole sport, but that's what I think of it, so you can stick it up your a--" Following a months-long investigation, the ACMA found Triple M breached decency rules by allowing "derogatory language and sexist themes" to be broadcast on the program.These included comments about the Matildas behaving like schoolgirls, which it said perpetuated stereotypes of women's behaviour. The ACMA also ruled that the comments demonstrated a "level of contempt and disdain" for women's sport and, more generally, women.The offensive themes were exacerbated by Sheargold's reference to his penis, it said. READ MORE: Albanese quickly changes shirt after fashion faux pas at crucial summit"Sexist comments like this don't belong in Australian broadcasting," ACMA member Carolyn Lidgerwood said."Even if the comments were an extremely ill-judged attempt at humour, a reasonable listener would have found them offensive and to have crossed the line."Sheargold issued an apology after his comments received widespread condemnation."Any comedy, including mine, can miss the mark sometimes, and I can see why people may have taken offence at my comments regarding the Matildas. I sincerely apologise," he said.He and Triple M mutually parted ways after the fallout, and his show was cancelled.The ACMA said it is considering enforcement action against Triple M.9news.com.au has contacted the owner of Triple M, Southern Cross Austero, for comment. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Sheargold's 'sexist' Matildas remarks breached decency rules
items.standfirst: An Australian media regulator investigation finds radio presenter Marty Sheargold's comments on Triple M "demeaning" and "demonstrated a level of contempt and disdain for women's sport".
items.content: An Australian media regulator investigation finds radio presenter Marty Sheargold's comments on Triple M "demeaning" and "demonstrated a level of contempt and disdain for women's sport".

ai_summary: A media investigation found comments were sexist and derogatory.
The investigation concerned remarks made by Marty Sheargold.
Sheargold's comments were made on Triple M radio.
The comments were about the Matildas, the Australian women's soccer team.
The investigation lasted for several months.

items.title: Jane Hume on rebuilding trust in the Liberal party - podcast
items.standfirst: The fallout in the Liberal party over Jacinta Nampijinpa Price’s inflammatory comments about Indian migrants has now culminated in her sacking from the shadow ministry by Sussan Ley. In the lead-up to this decision by the opposition leader, Victorian senator Jane Hume described it as a situation that ‘escalated well out of control’. Hume speaks to chief political correspondent Tom McIlroy about the need for her party to rebuild the trust of mainstream Australia – and why she thinks this was eroded during the election campaignRead more: Continue reading...

items.title: The rules of political gravity have set in for Jacinta Nampijinpa Price – but the Coalition is still in a dangerous limbo
items.standfirst: Price’s refusal to endorse Sussan Ley’s leadership on Wednesday was a deliberate provocation that left the opposition leader no choiceReport: Ley dumps Nampijinpa Price from shadow ministry over refusal to back leadership or apologise over migrants commentsFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastFor much of her short career in Canberra, the usual rules of political gravity have appeared not to apply to Jacinta Nampijinpa Price.A firebrand, outspoken and unapologetic about almost everything, she went from a first-term backbencher from the Northern Territory to a member of the shadow cabinet in less than a term. Easily the most prominent opponent of the Indigenous voice to parliament, Price used the referendum campaign to build her political brand exponentially.Tom McIlroy is Guardian Australia’s chief political correspondent Continue reading...
